1.rationale:
Let’s review our current situation:

• Our snake (#1) is now at (6,3) with a body segment behind us at (6,4).  
• The enemy snake (#0) is at (6,1).  
• The remaining apples are at (2,6), (8,2), (1,8), (0,4), and (4,6).  
• From our head (6,3), the apple at (8,2) is the closest (Manhattan distance: |8–6| + |2–3| = 2 + 1 = 3).

Looking at our possible moves from (6,3):

– UP would take us to (6,4), which is already occupied by our own body. That’s a collision.  
– DOWN would bring our head to (6,2). Although that moves us closer to (8,2), it puts us in the same vertical column as enemy snake (#0) at (6,1). Being too close to the enemy’s position might present head-on collision risks on subsequent turns.  
– LEFT (to (5,3)) is safe but does little to reduce our distance to the apple at (8,2).  
– RIGHT moves us to (7,3) and increases our distance from the enemy snake while keeping us on track for (8,2). From (7,3), we can easily maneuver (e.g., moving RIGHT to (8,3) then DOWN to (8,2)) to reach that apple.

Therefore, to pursue the closest apple safely while keeping away from the enemy, my decided next move is: RIGHT.
